acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96 hours EC50=0.91mg/L of the algae (Chlorella) (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report, 2004).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 324mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 268mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)), 568mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)), 650 mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)), 268 mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)), 270 mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)), 893 mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)), 400 mg/kg (IUCLID (2000))

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Group 2B by IARC (1996).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity is Category 1 and bio-accumulation is low (log Kow=1.98(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition of dinitrotoluene by BOD: 0%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Because of a lack of data on the kick-off temperature and decomposition energy (though the substance contains nitro groups, with its oxygen budget calculated at -144). Classified into Divisiton 6.1 (UN#1600 dinitrotoluene (molten)) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods). Commercial dinitrotoluene, which contains about 20% of 2,6-dinitrotoluene, starts to decompose at 250degC -- a process that continues at 280degC (Bretherick (J), 5th, 1998). The decomposition energy stands at about 85% of that of TNT (2,4,6-trinitrotoluene) (5.1kJ/g) (Bretherick (J), 5th, 1998), according to some reports.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1600 dinitrotoluene (molten)) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests), the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests) and the absence of data on germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.51 (2004).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: No data available, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen. Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1600 dinitrotoluene (molten)) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1600 dinitrotoluene (molten)) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the description in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.51 (2004): The results of rat 3-generation reproduction studies suggest a decrease in the survival rate of newborns at dose levels toxic to parent animals; those of tests on male genital organs suggest atrophy of seminiferous tubules and severe spermatogenic disorder at dose levels causing adverse effects on body weight gain.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available - melting point: 71degC (ICSC, 1999), test temperature: 140degC

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1600 dinitrotoluene (molten)) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.51 (2004)): "mild irritation" (though exposure time is unknown).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.51 (2004)): "mild irritation" (though exposure time is unknown).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, blood, nervous system, testis)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "hepatocellular degeneration, hyperplasia of the bile duct epithelium, methemoglobinemia, anemia, demyelination of the brain stem and cerebellum, neuropathy, atrophy of testes" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.51 (2004)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1. Refer to GHS classification of "a mixture with dinitrotoluene isomers containing more than 70% of dinitrotoluene" (CAS#25321-14-6) made by the program. Commercial dinitrotoluene contains about 75% of 2,4- dinitrotoluene and 20% of 2,6- dinitrotoluene (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.51 (2004)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Classification not possible, because of a lack of data, although specific target organs appear to be the blood and nervous systems, based on the evidence from animal studies including "cyanosis and dystonia, with rats showing higher sensitivity to lethal action than mice" (ATSDR 1998). Refer to GHS classification of "a mixture with dinitrotoluene isomers containing more than 70% of dinitrotoluene" (CAS#25321-14-6) made by the program. Commercial dinitrotoluene contains about 75% of 2,4- dinitrotoluene and 20% of 2,6- dinitrotoluene (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.51 (2004)).
